hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, sought, the warriors, there in the group of one is a village filled with great people, and so on, those people. They went to the field of Keahumoa, they entered inside the house, no people. They were silent, returning, a question from Nāmakaokapāo'o on the edge of the village. They spoke in the voice, no one knows of the mind, they asked: "How are you doing this?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "It is only me here." They poured water for the people, they are in the mouth of the house, they are in the side of the house, and all of Nāmakaokapāo'o. They asked: "What is here of your son?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "We came here to fight with Nāmakaokapāo'o, a place for the children of the sea like you, a place of strength and the mighty, he only fights with his husband, Puali'i."
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>  
Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, sought, the warriors, there in the group of one is a village filled with great people, and so on, those people. They went to the field of Keahumoa, they entered inside the house, no people. They were silent, returning, a question from Nāmakaokapāo'o on the edge of the village. They spoke in the voice, no one knows of the mind, they asked: "How are you doing this?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "It is only me here." They poured water for the people, they are in the mouth of the house, they are in the side of the house, and all of Nāmakaokapāo'o. They asked: "What is here of your son?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "We came here to fight with Nāmakaokapāo'o, a place for the children of the sea like you, a place of strength and the mighty, he only fights with his husband, Puali'i."  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
• [Main interpretive point about the passage]  
  – [The narrative reflects a tension between traditional warrior values and the collapse of the kapu system after 1819, symbolizing the erosion of social hierarchy and spiritual authority.]  
  – [The fragmented structure and repetition of "ehā" (they) suggest a disruption in communal order, mirroring the societal upheaval during the 'Ai Kapu era and its aftermath.]  

• [Analysis of character names or symbolism]  
  – [Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o: "Nā" (plural), "maka" (sea/daughter), "o" (possessive), "ka-pāo'o" (edge/boundary). "Nāmakaokapāo'o" as "Daughter of the boundary" or "Edge of the sea," symbolizing a liminal space between tradition and change.]  
  – ["Puali'i" (to be broken/shattered): Represents the vulnerability of traditional structures under post-1820 missionary influence, where old practices were dismantled.]  

• [Historical or cultural context point]  
  – [The "kula o Keahumoa" (field of Keahumoa) may reference a sacred or contested space, aligning with the 'Ai Kapu era's emphasis on ritual purity and territorial boundaries.]  
  – [The phrase "kānaka ka nui" (great people) alludes to the *kānaka* (human) as central to *kuleana* (responsibility), reflecting the pre-contact social structure where ali’i (chief) and kaua (warriors) held distinct roles.]  

• [Allegorical meaning of "komo lākou ā loko o ka hale"]  
  – [The act of "entering inside the house" (komo ā loko o ka hale) symbolizes the intrusion of foreign values or the collapse of sacred spaces, as seen in the post-1820 missionary era when traditional *heiau* (temples) were abandoned.]  
  – [The absence of "kanaka" (people) in the house mirrors the 1819 abolition of the *Ai Kapu*, where social structures were dismantled, and the old order gave way to new hierarchies.]  

• [Symbolism of "kālea mai Nāmakaokapāo'o"]  
  – ["Eia nō wau i luna nei" ("It is only me here") reflects the isolation of ali’i during the transition period, as traditional leadership faced challenges from missionary influence and Westernization.]  
  – [The dialogue "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" ("What is here of your son?") critiques the erasure of lineage and the commodification of Hawaiian identity under colonialism, where *kānaka* (people) were redefined by external narratives.]  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
